Posted By: Polychromatic (10/10/2011 7:38:21 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
I discovered why cards like [Gaea's Cradle](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Gaea's Cradle), [Show and Tell](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Show and Tell), [Sneak Attack](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Sneak Attack), [Rofellos, Llanowar Emissary](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Rofellos, Llanowar Emissary), and [Tolarian Academy](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Tolarian Academy) (or the Urza block in general) were printed back then, and are still amazing.  
  
They're reliant on what you have to play.   
  
Back then, what could you Sneak Attack in? One of the best, high-costed spell from that block was [Multani, Maro-Sorcerer](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Multani, Maro-Sorcerer). A great card to this day, but you wouldn't use it in your legacy deck.   
No, you'd play [Emrakul](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Emrakul), [Ulamog](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Ulamog), [Kozilek](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Kozilek), or any other Eldrazi instead.   
These cards may seem like the biggest cards in the game, but what if they create something that's bigger?  
  
These time-tested cards are reliant on what you could play, and the more cards are created, the better these cards get.   
  
My point is that Snapcaster is exactly that: a time-tested card. He cou... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)

They're reliant on what you have to play.

Back then, what could you Sneak Attack in? One of the best, high-costed spell from that block was Multani, Maro-Sorcerer. A great card to this day, but you wouldn't use it in your legacy deck.
No, you'd play Emrakul, Ulamog, Kozilek, or any other Eldrazi instead.
These cards may seem like the biggest cards in the game, but what if they create something that's bigger?

These time-tested cards are reliant on what you could play, and the more cards are created, the better these cards get.

My point is that Snapcaster is exactly that: a time-tested card. He cou... (see all)

Posted By: DacenOctavio (12/27/2012 2:48:05 AM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
Awesome card, but seems out-of-place with the flavor of Innistrad. I'll admit he's got the cool gavony style paldrons and a zappy gun that appears to be powered by geists, however his expression is of distant longing.   
He pines for the wonderful plane of Ravnica where he can share his knowledge of flashback mechanics with the Izzet guild and get in heated, sexually tense arguments with [Ash Zealot](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Ash Zealot)  
  
Nothing would make him happier than to look downward and see the little golden Ravnica symbol at his feet, but with a sigh he soldiers on, reluctantly helping the foolish townsfolk stave off the vile creatures that dwell in the dark plane of Innistrad.
posts.html:

Posted By: aliz_com (10/21/2012 2:28:05 AM)
Rating:

@Grimjaw: I don't think people are 1-starring this card in an attempt to lower its secondary market price so that they can buy a set cheaply after tricking retailers into thinking nobody likes it. That would be silly of them. Rather, I think the low ratings come from the belief that this card is so powerful that it's not fun.

Not being a tournament player, I've never seen Snapcaster in use, so I'm abstaining from rating him. However, I agree with the general sentiment. Magic will be the most fun the more viable ways there are to win, and so when one card shows up in the majority of all winning decks, people get tired of seeing it.

Community ratings aren't about whether a card is good, they're about whether you personally like the card. Normally those two go hand in hand, but in cases like this, people have every right to give 1 star to a card they wish didn't exist, no matter how powerful it is. In any case, if you like Snapcaster Mage, you already know how good it is and aren'... (see all)

Posted By: Teh_Kitchen (10/2/2011 11:53:06 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
FLASHBACK ALL THE SPELLS!! :D  
  
This card is nothing short of amazing. It literally fits into every deck playing blue. Burn, milling, tutors, counterspells, spot removal. You name it; Snapcaster does it all, and gives you a 2/1 creature to boot! If this card doesn't scream utility, then I don't know what does, and I honestly don't know why this isn't rated at least +4.5/5.  
Complaining about the price tag and rating it down won't affect the secondary market price. What matters is whether or not people are using it at tournaments, and whether or not people are winning with this. If you're upset about it costing too much, complain to the store owners instead, and give this card the proper rating it deserves. (And no, I'm not saying this because I'm some rich smart-buttocks who can afford throwing +20 $ away for a piece of cardboard. Walletslayer contined to see play and be expensive even though people rated it below 4 out of spite: raging in Gatherer's comment section won't help.)  
  
Oh yeah... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)
